title: 108_hr4019
content: Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization is addressed in Section 1. Congress finds that good health is crucial for all citizens worldwide, emphasizing the importance of access to high-quality health information and services. They highlight the benefits of direct participation in international health cooperation, especially in combating infectious diseases like HIV, tuberculosis, and malaria. Taiwan's significant population and achievements in health make a strong case for its inclusion in the World Health Organization. Taiwan has achieved high life expectancy levels in Asia, comparable maternal and infant mortality rates to western countries, eradicated infectious diseases like cholera and polio, and provided hepatitis B vaccinations to children. Taiwan has collaborated closely with the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on public health issues. On January 14, 2001, Taiwan sent rescue teams and relief aid to El Salvador after a devastating earthquake. Taiwan has also expressed willingness to assist in international health activities supported by the WHO. Foreign Affairs donated $200,000 in relief aid to the Salvadoran Government. The World Health Assembly allowed observers from various organizations to participate in its activities. The United States declared support for Taiwan's participation in international organizations. Public Law 106-137 required a report on efforts to support Taiwan's participation in the WHO. Taiwan's participation in the WHO can bring benefits to health in the state. Taiwan should have meaningful participation in the WHO, as supported by President Bush in 2001. The focus is on finding ways for Taiwan to benefit and contribute to the organization. In 2002, Secretary of Health and Human Services Tommy Thompson announced support for Taiwan's efforts to gain observership status at the World Health Assembly, emphasizing the importance of public health for the people of Taiwan. In response to global health crises, the Government of Taiwan donated $1,000,000 to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria in 2002. Taiwan also experienced outbreaks of SARS and bird flu in 2003, highlighting the importance of global cooperation in healthcare. The importance of global cooperation in healthcare is emphasized by outbreaks like SARS and avian influenza, showing that diseases have no boundaries. It is crucial for all countries, including Taiwan, to have access to international health organizations like the WHO. The Secretary of Health and Human Services recognized the need for effective public health worldwide. The Secretary of State is authorized to endorse and obtain observer status for Taiwan at international summits. The Secretary of State is authorized to endorse and obtain observer status for Taiwan at the World Health Assembly summit in Geneva, Switzerland. A report on this plan must be submitted to Congress annually. The Secretary of State is required to submit an annual report to Congress detailing efforts to endorse Taiwan for observer status at the World Health Assembly summit in Geneva, Switzerland. The report must include steps taken to promote Taiwan's bid and obtain observer status at the next meeting. The House of Representatives passed the bill on April 21, 2004.
